title: 103_s2126
content: The "Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act" allows for interstate transportation and disposal of municipal solid waste under the Solid Waste Disposal Act. The "Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act" restricts out-of-state waste disposal at landfills or incinerators unless authorized by the affected local government through formal written approval. The "Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act" requires affected local governments to obtain specific information from facility owners before granting authorization to receive out-of-state municipal solid waste. The "Local Government Interstate Waste Control Act" requires affected local governments to obtain specific information from facility owners before granting authorization to receive out-of-state municipal solid waste, including details on waste volume, facility site map, and environmental characteristics. The curr_chunk discusses environmental controls for a facility site, including runon or runoff management, air pollution control devices, source separation procedures, methane monitoring, landfill covers, liners, leachate collection systems, and waste residuals management. It also includes site access controls. The curr_chunk provides details on site access controls, roadway improvements, required permits, and personnel requirements for a facility. It includes estimates of increased local truck traffic, necessary permits, and personnel skill and education levels before and after facility operation. The curr_chunk outlines the information required by State law regarding violations of environmental laws, gifts and contributions, and compliance by the owner or operator of a facility. The curr_chunk discusses the notification process required before granting authorization to receive out-of-State municipal solid waste. It includes notifying the Governor, adjoining local governments, and Indian tribes, as well as publishing notice in a newspaper before holding a hearing. The local government must provide public notification and opportunity for comment before granting authorization for out-of-State municipal solid waste. They must also notify the Governor, adjoining local governments, and Indian tribes of the authorization. Landfills and incinerators already in operation or under construction are exempt from these requirements. Before the enactment of this section, the owner or operator must have received documented shipments of out-of-State municipal solid waste or obtained authorization from the local government. The landfill must comply with all relevant Federal and State laws regarding design, location standards, and environmental regulations. The owner or operator of a landfill or incinerator must comply with location standards, leachate collection, groundwater monitoring, and financial assurance requirements. For incinerators, compliance with Clean Air Act requirements is necessary. Documentation of municipal solid waste shipments must be provided to the State Governor. The Governor has the authority to restrict out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal at landfills upon request from local government and solid waste planning units. The restriction can limit the quantity of waste received for disposal during a 1-year period. The landfill in the State can limit out-of-state municipal solid waste disposal upon request from local government and solid waste planning units. Procedural requirements must be met before submitting a request. The waste planning unit must provide notice, allow public comment, and take formal action at a public meeting for proposed requests. The Governor must respond consistently without discrimination towards any landfill or out-of-state waste shipments based on origin. The Governor's authority is limited in this matter. The Governor's authority to regulate waste disposal is limited by state law and existing contracts for out-of-state waste. This section does not affect agreements in effect before its enactment. The owner or operator of a landfill or incinerator exempt from certain requirements must provide public access to contracts for out-of-State waste disposal. Information such as waste volume, source, and contract duration must be disclosed. This section applies to all states unless a state rejects its applicability. A State can be exempt from certain requirements by notifying the Administrator and making specific reference to the section. The Administrator will acknowledge the exemption. Definitions in this section include "affected local government." The term 'affected local government' refers to elected officials with primary jurisdiction over a landfill or incinerator site. 'Host agreement' is a binding agreement between facility owners and local governments allowing waste disposal. The term 'municipal solid waste' refers to solid waste generated by the general public or from various sources, including paper, wood, yard wastes, food wastes, plastics, and other materials. It excludes hazardous waste, industrial waste, and medical waste. The term 'out-of-State municipal solid waste' refers to waste generated outside of a specific state. The term 'owner or operator' refers to individuals responsible for managing waste facilities. The term 'owner or operator' excludes state or local governments that own or operate landfills within their jurisdiction, as well as individuals who only receive waste they generate. Interstate transportation and disposal of municipal solid waste is addressed in Sec. 4011.
